title: Daily Mail's guide to the Indian capital of Delhi
text:
37 shares 14
View
comments
The mighty Indian capital is, for many visitors, little more than a launch pad for the forts and deserts of Rajasthan to the west and the marbled splendour of the Taj Mahal to the south. They are missing out.
Yes, Delhi is chaotic and overwhelming, but it’s also wonderfully rewarding. And now’s the time to go. The city is cooling down after a summer that saw temperatures surge to 44c — and the introduction of new online visas has made India more accessible than ever.
Humayun's Tomb in Delhi is a beautiful spot that should not be missed out on
OLD SPICE
Originally a walled city built in the 17th century by Emperor Shah Jahan, historic Old Delhi remains a lively enclave of mosques, forts, markets and back streets, where the hot air sizzles with frying samosas. Chandni Chowk is like London’s Oxford Street on hallucinogenic drugs. At the eastern end stands the imposing Red Fort, a Mughal masterpiece built from sandstone in the mid 1600s.
SERENE SCENE
New Delhi, by comparison, is peaceful, with tree-lined boulevards plotted a century ago by the British Raj. Stand under the Arc de Triomphe-inspired India Gate, built to honour those who fell in World War I, and visit Gandhi Smriti, the house-turned-museum where the ‘Father of India’ was assassinated in 1948.

Delhi has embraced its creative side with several galleries springing up. One of the most cutting-edge is Exhibit320 ( exhibit320.com ). Elsewhere, the National Gallery of Modern Art ( ngmaindia.gov.in ) is housed in a former palace.
ON YER BIKE
Take to the streets with Delhi ByCycle ( delhibycycle.com ). Guided cycling tours at dawn (when the city is quieter) reveal the sights while dodging honking cars, buses, rickshaws, goats and stray dogs. Thrilling and a little terrifying.
A visit to Delhi gives a fantastic opportunity to taste some real tandoori dishes
DELHI BELLY
No, not that Delhi belly. Delhi is one of India’s culinary hotspots. Don’t miss the aromatic black lentil dhal, cooked for more than 18 hours, at Bukhara ( itchotels.in ) in New Delhi. Presidents Obama and Clinton have both eaten there.
The adventurous should head to Karim’s ( karimhoteldelhi.com ), one of the city’s oldest restaurants; a no-frills institution famed for its tandooris and goat brain curry.
BED DOWN
A hotel fit for a maharaja, The Oberoi New Delhi ( oberoihotels.com ) offers plush rooms with pillow menus, a pool and heavenly spa (try the Indian foot massage). Ask for an east-facing room for views of Humayun’s Tomb, the 16th-century, Persian-style complex that inspired the Taj Mahal in Agra.
